rounds.response:
The position after 1.e4 e5 2.Nf3 Nf6 is a critical line of the Open Game, often leading to the Ruy López or Italian structures. The most principled move for White is to develop with tempo by attacking the f6 knight.

The move [f3g5] attacks the knight on f6, threatening to win the e5 pawn if Black is not careful. However, this only works if the knight moves — which it can, safely.

Instead, the most common and strong move is to develop the bishop to **c4**, targeting f7 and preparing for quick castling. This leads to the Italian Game, one of the oldest and most respected openings.

Thus, I play:

[c2c4]

rounds.response:
[Analysis] White has just lunged [f3g5], which threatens to win the e5 pawn if I move the knight.  
The direct way to punish this ambitious move is with …d5, striking the center and gaining tempo since the knight has no good squares (f7 is still protected; on e4 or d4 the knight will come under fire).  
After the likely sequence …d5, Nxe5, …Qxg5 White will not recover adequate material and my central pawn mass will be strong.

[Move]
[d7d5]

Instead, the most common and strong move is to develop the bishop to **c4**, targeting f7 and preparing for quick castling. This leads to the Italian Game, one of the oldest and most respected openings.

White’s knight has jumped to g5 hitting f7.  
The three main defensive ideas are:

1. …h6 — kicking the knight with the h-pawn (simplest);  
2. …d5 — hitting the centre and opening lines;  
3. …Na6-c5 — counter-attacking with a piece.

After …h6 h4-h5 the knight often swings to f3 anyway, and Black keeps several constructive continuations. It is very safe and typical at club level.

Hence I play:

[h7h6]

After the immediate …d6 the bishop on c8 can then slide to e7 in one move, keeping maximum flexibility and preparing short castling.

rounds.response:
[Analysis]  
White has just played c2-c4, a move characteristic of the English Opening transposed into an e-pawn formation.  
Black already has the pawn majority d6+e5 vs White’s d- and e-files, so the standard plan is:

1. Build a firm centre with …c6 (guarding against a White d4 push).  
2. Finish kingside development with …Be7 (or …Bc5), …0-0.  
3. Possibly develop the light-squared bishop to e6 or g4, and the queenside knight to c6.

The immediate striking attempt …d5 is premature because after cxd5 Nxd5(?) e4 creates pressure.

The most flexible, classical continuation is therefore:  

[Move]
[c8e6]

The move [f3g5] attacks the knight on f6, threatening to win the e5 pawn if Black is not careful. However, this only works if the knight moves — which it can, safely.

Instead, the most common and strong move is to develop the bishop to **c4**, targeting f7 and preparing for quick castling. This leads to the Italian Game, one of the oldest and most respected openings.

Thus, I play:

[c2c4]

rounds.response:
[Analysis]  
White has lunged with c4-c5, hitting d6.  
The most consistent reply is simply to take on d4 after …d6xc5 and then …Bf5/Be7, but the immediate capture involves giving up the dark-square anchor.

Instead, mobilise central pressure with the traditional Philidor/Larsen-style break:

1. …d5 hits the White centre and opens lines for the light-square bishop, freeing the c8 diagonal.

If White accepts the pawn with cxd5, Bxd5 gives Black excellent piece harmony and central control.

[Move]  
[d6d5]

rounds.response:
[Analysis]  
White just pushed c5–c6, handing Black a nice square d7 for a knight (Bxd7 is no longer dangerous: the bishop is already exchanged) and the long-term hope that the c-pawn can be blockaded on c7.  
Immediate exploitation is the key:

- **b7xc6** breaks White’s pawn mass, opens the b-file for the rook, and leaves the c6-barrier on a light square that White can’t attack with dark-square pieces.  
- There’s no real pawn weakness, since b7xc6 and …dxc6 won’t leave anything crippled on the c6 point; the c-pawn is locked, and the centre is firm.  
- After natural recapture …Bc5 & …0-0 Black will have comfortable space and pressure along the open b-file.

[Move]  
[b7xc6]
[GAME]

Either way keeps Black's position fully sound; the central tension is immediately resolved and development remains complete.

rounds.response:
[Analysis]  
White’s play has ended up rather passive—g3 followed by Rg1–g2 frees the rook only to its own kingside.  
Black, on the other hand, is fully developed, has rooks already doubled on the back rank, the minor piece on e4 is excellently centralized, and White’s pawn on d2 blocks in both bishop and knight.

Currently the knight on e4 is unassailable; its only “threat” to itself is the one-move retreat Bf5–e6, all while Black enjoys open d-file pressure after possible …Kh7/…Rg8.

A simple, natural plan is therefore:

1.count Centre stability – no immediate pressure:
   - …c6-c5 cuts off the d-file for a moment, and if dxc5 Rd8 regains the pawn with gain of tempo.
   - If that’s accepted, we may recapture with Nxc5 and the queenside structure becomes even more solid.

2.Protection for advanced knight – suggest …b8–d7 with potential to
   - migrate to f6 or re-capture on c5
   - provide flexibility for …Rfc8 double rook pressure.

Thus, the most immediate, tempo-gaining attack on the position is:

[Move]  
[c6c5]

[Analysis]  
White has just pushed g3-g4?—a heavy weakening of his kingside pawn structure (g4 is now a glaring hole on the light squares).  
Black already enjoys the centralized knight on e4; the rook on e8, the f-file half-open after …f7xe6, and the attacking potential along the newly-opened g-file is excellent.

Tactics appear: e4xg3 forks the rook on g2 and the queenless position suddenly becomes powerful for Black. The rook on g2 is only defended by the king should the knight jump.

Thus:

[Move]  
[e4g3]

The move [f3g5] attacks the knight on f6, threatening to win the e5 pawn if Black is not careful. However, this only works if the knight moves — which it can, safely.

Instead, the most common and strong move is to develop the bishop to **c4**, targeting f7 and preparing for quick castling. This leads to the Italian Game, one of the oldest and most respected openings.

Thus, I play:

The knight is on g3, pressuring the rook now on …h-moved-to-g3—and already the rook holds it. White has kingside pawn weaknesses (g4), while Black’s pieces are very active:

- Rook on e8 holds a central leash.  
- Light-squared bishop on d5 is already doing a great job blocking the d-file pawn and is poised to increase pressure.  
- G-file has good prospects for a rook to double on/e.g. rg8 or rg6 after …g7-g5 etc.

The natural refinement is to improve the rook on a8: immediately bring it round to the open c-file where it can press the queenside pawn majority and keep pressure on White’s far-side.

Therefore:

[a8c8]

The move [f3g5] attacks the knight on f6, threatening to win the e5 pawn if Black is not careful. However, this only works if the knight moves — which it can, safely.
